stories.headline: State expects busy holiday weekend
stories.summary: Arkansas parks and highways are expected to be busy over the Memorial Day holiday weekend, with beautiful weather predicted. Officials from Pinnacle Mountain State Park anticipate thousands of visitors for outdoor activities like camping, boating, and hiking. Increased travel and outdoor recreation are typical during this peak season.

stories.headline: State justices rule to allow AG’s suit against prisons board
stories.summary: The Arkansas Supreme Court allowed Attorney General Tim Griffin to continue a lawsuit alleging violations by the state Board of Corrections. The board's solicitor general did not participate in the decision. The lawsuit claims the board violated state open meetings laws when it hired a controversial attorney, and the case will proceed to assess if any violations occurred.

stories.headline: Plane crash in San Diego
stories.summary: A small plane crashed in a neighborhood in San Diego, causing several blocks to catch fire. Emergency responders were at the scene, attending to the crash site. Five employees on board were killed, including a co-founder who owned the plane. The cause of the crash is under investigation.

stories.headline: Trustees for UA approve tuition
stories.summary: The University of Arkansas System Board of Trustees approved tuition rates for the 2025-26 academic year, with most schools seeing slight increases in fees. The adjustments come as the universities prepare for the upcoming academic year amid ongoing discussions about affordability and education funding.
people: University of Arkansas System Board of Trustees

stories.headline: Governor: State will cover 35% of storm repair
stories.summary: Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced that Arkansas will cover 35% of the costs to clean up and rebuild damaged infrastructure from recent March storms after FEMA declined federal aid. Local agencies will assist with repairs, with the state stepping in to help affected areas. The announcement follows President Donald Trump reversing an earlier decision to deny federal funds, acknowledging the extensive damage sustained in the storms.

stories.headline: House passes sweeping tax cuts package
stories.summary: House Republicans passed a multi-trillion-dollar tax breaks package, with Speaker Mike Johnson unifying his ranks to advance President Donald Trump's priority bill. Despite last-minute concessions and warnings from Trump, opposition from Democrats remains strong. The bill aims to put more money in Americans' pockets but faces debate in the Senate. Mixed market reactions were observed as investors weighed the news amid ongoing economic concerns.

stories.headline: Trump highlights South Africa's 'Kill the boer' chant
stories.summary: During a tense White House meeting with South African leader Cyril Ramaphosa, President Donald Trump highlighted footage of South African politicians chanting 'kill the boer, the farmer.' The chant ties back to the struggle against white majority rule and apartheid. Trump questioned why those involved had not been arrested. The clip showed leaders singing the chant and discussing land expropriation, reflecting ongoing tensions between the US and South Africa over issues of race and land rights.

stories.headline: 2 Israeli Embassy aides fatally shot outside DC event
stories.summary: Two young Israeli Embassy aides were shot and killed outside an event at the Capitol Jewish Museum in Washington DC by a man shouting pro-Palestinian slogans. The suspect, Elias Rodriguez, was detained and no ongoing threat to public safety was reported. Israel identified the victims as Yaron Lischinsky and Shach Lynn Milgrim, both young Embassy staffers. The incident has led to security concerns and condemnation, with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu calling it an act of antisemitism.

stories.headline: House passes domestic policy bill, overcoming resistance
stories.summary: The House narrowly passed a wide-ranging bill to deliver on President Donald Trump's domestic agenda, overcoming resistance from mini-rebellions in Republican ranks. The legislation would slash taxes, steer more money to military and border security, and provide cuts to Medicaid, food assistance, education, and clean energy programs, aiming to reduce federal deficits. Passage of the bill is a crucial victory for Trump and Republicans pushing the 'big, beautiful bill' as part of their unified Democratic opposition battle.

stories.headline: DOJ moves to end Louisville consent decree, police reform
stories.summary: The federal government is dismissing a consent decree and lawsuit aimed at reforming the Louisville Metro Police Department. Louisville signed a historic consent decree with the Justice Department in December 2024 to address civil rights violations in the department including use of force, reporting, data collection, and arrests. The move comes years after public outcry following the fatal police shooting of Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old Black woman and emergency room technician.
people: Former U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland

stories.headline: Golden, Pingree blast GOP budget after its passage
stories.summary: U.S. Representatives Jared Golden and Chellie Pingree criticized a Republican budget bill that cleared the House, which includes cuts to Medicaid and other programs affecting wealthy Americans. The bill, pushed through with last-minute amendments, is over 1,000 pages long and would impose $800 million in Medicaid, cut taxes, and increase border security and clean-energy tax credits. The Senate will now review the bill. Concerns have been raised by Maine's Susan Collins and other Republicans about the impact of these cuts.

stories.headline: Conservation effort along Appalachian Trail hits snag
stories.summary: Somerset County officials have raised objections to a land trust’s plan to purchase 1,845 acres near Moxie Pond for conservation, fearing it would restrict hunting access. Despite being a long-planned deal with the National Park Service to protect forestland, some county commissioners have expressed concern over the impact of the acquisition. The project might lose over $2 million in federal funding if opposition persists.

stories.headline: Homeland Security revokes Harvard's ability to enroll international students
stories.summary: The Trump administration revoked Harvard University's ability to enroll international students amid escalating tensions with the Ivy League school. Thousands of current students must transfer to other schools or leave the country as part of the Department of Homeland Security's new action, citing Harvard's creation of an unsafe campus environment. The university labeled the action as 'unlawful'.

stories.headline: Running with the fishes
stories.summary: Alewives are making their annual migration up Maine rivers, a natural event to witness by being persistent. Despite the unpredictability of when and where the fish appear, the article encourages people to catch a glimpse of this natural wonder, highlighting last year's exceptional expectations and personal experiences with Alewife migration in various locations like Mill Brook Preserve in Westbrook.

stories.headline: House passes budget, tax bill; what it means for California
stories.summary: California lawmakers passed a budget and tax bill that will impact state and local deductions, along with federal income tax rates. The bill maintains current income tax rates but changes deductions: the standard deduction for California and other higher-tax states has increased, and the $10,000 state and local tax deductions were raised to $40,000 for qualifying taxpayers. The bill fulfills President Trump's mandate to end the prior tax policy and delivers benefits to families and voters who rely on state and local deductions.

stories.headline: 'Bewildering': Lawmakers criticize RTO mandate’s murky costs
stories.summary: Lawmakers expressed frustration and criticism over the state's Renewable Transportation Overlay (RTO) mandate due to the unclear and potentially high costs associated with it. Less than six weeks before the deadline, state officials cannot estimate the costs to bring workers back to offices four days a week. The lack of clear information has caused bewilderment and disappointment among lawmakers and state workers. Concerns include the financial impact on workers and the difficulties in addressing affordability challenges.

stories.headline: Kiley scores win against longtime nemesis Newsom
stories.summary: Republican Congressman Kevin Kiley won a legislative battle against California Governor Gavin Newsom by helping pass three bills to phase out gasoline-powered vehicles. This is regarded as a significant victory against Newsom, who has been a formidable opponent. Kiley's recent success is seen as his biggest political triumph and a challenge to Newsom's leadership, as expressed in his efforts to hold Newsom accountable through legislation and public discourse.

stories.headline: California to sue after Congress blocks state's emissions waiver
stories.summary: California plans to sue Congress after its unprecedented move to revoke the state's waiver on gasoline-powered cars by 2035. The waiver, managed by the California Air Resources Board and the California Environmental Protection Agency, allowed California to enforce stricter climate emission standards than federal guidelines. The state's move is in response to Congress' decision to revoke this waiver, which has raised concerns about ongoing climate protection efforts and the political implications of this federal action.

stories.headline: Report examines health of US kids
stories.summary: The White House released an extensive report detailing the health challenges facing children in the United States, focusing on the impact of chronic diseases linked to ultraprocessed foods, chemical exposures, sedentary lifestyles, stress, and excessive prescription drug use. The report, created by a presidential commission led by Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., calls for new research initiatives but stops short of specific policy recommendations. It echoes longstanding concerns about the wellbeing of children nationally.

stories.headline: US Mint to put an end to printing the penny
stories.summary: The U.S. Mint announced plans to cease production of the penny, citing increased costs of making the coin and reduced demand. This decision follows official confirmation from the Treasury Department and comes amid the Trump administration's moves to streamline coin production and reduce expenses. The final penny run is expected to mark the end of an era for American currency as the government considers phasing out the historically contentious coin.

stories.headline: A Dalton welcome
stories.summary: Friends and classmates of Ximena Arias-Cristobal, a student recently released from ICE detention, decorated her bedroom in anticipation of her homecoming in Dalton. Arias-Cristobal's friends emphasize the emotional difficulty she faces reintegrating after her detention, where she was held for over two months following an immigration arrest. The community response highlights support for her and calls attention to the challenges faced by individuals detained under immigration enforcement policies.

stories.headline: Erlanger buys rights to name new stadium
stories.summary: Erlanger Health has purchased the naming rights to the $115 million Chattanooga Lookouts stadium under construction, which will be called Erlanger Park starting from the 2026 season. This deal strengthens the long-standing relationship between Erlanger and Chattanooga Lookouts, with the hospital system now acting as the stadium's largest partner. The naming rights investment supports various ongoing development efforts and highlights the collaboration between local government and private nonprofit entities.

stories.headline: National cemetery can finally cut grass
stories.summary: The Santa Fe National Cemetery can now begin restoring its grounds after years of grass being overgrown due to postponed maintenance. A contract has been approved to restore the grass, just in time for Memorial Day weekend, ensuring the cemetery will be more presentable to visitors paying respects during this significant holiday.

stories.headline: House OKs immigration, tax measure
stories.summary: The House approved President Donald Trump's expansive tax and immigration agenda, which includes imposing restrictions on immigrants and significant tax cuts for corporations and some individuals. The measure, also known as Trump's Big Beautiful Bill, encompasses extensive new spending and tax breaks, though it faces criticism for adding substantial deficits and cutting crucial programs.

stories.headline: Website woes irk candidates
stories.summary: Santa Fe City Council hopefuls expressed frustration with the rollout of the election website, which had rocky beginnings and raised concerns about equal recognition and donations. Some candidates were not informed about the website's inclusion in the election process and faced challenges with digital signatures and public financing applications.

stories.headline: Campers face fire restrictions
stories.summary: Due to drought conditions, many of New Mexico's national forests, including the Santa Fe National Forest, are under fire restrictions just as the Memorial Day weekend begins. The restrictions limit camping facilities and caution visitors to be aware of fire risks, as some popular campgrounds have been closed to prevent wildfires.

stories.headline: Indianapolis Colts Owner
stories.summary: Jim Irsay, owner of the Indianapolis Colts, passed away at age 65. He led the team to a Super Bowl victory in 2006 and was known for his commitment to the sport and community. His death marks the end of an era for the franchise and the local sports community.

stories.headline: Tight House Vote Passes Deep Cuts in Taxes and Aid: A Victory for Trump
stories.summary: The House narrowly passed a major bill championed by President Trump that drastically cuts taxes and federal aid programs. The contentious legislation, which passed by a slim margin, reduces military, social services, and Medicaid spending while also aiming to lower the national debt. The bill's passage represents a significant win for Trump’s domestic agenda amidst fierce opposition from Democratic members and public debate about the impacts of the budget cuts.

stories.headline: Harvard Loses Ability to Take Any Foreigners: Trump Targets Critical Funding Source
stories.summary: The Trump administration announced a policy that restricts Harvard University’s ability to enroll international students, aiming to cut funding sources linked to elite higher education institutions. This move is part of broader governmental actions targeting academia's influence and affiliations with progressive agendas. The administration’s decision has sparked debate over the future of academic diversity and funding flows in the U.S.

stories.headline: A Gifted Couple, Just Days From His Proposing
stories.summary: Sarah Lynn Milgrim, on the cusp of a marriage proposal from her partner, was tragically shot near the Jewish Museum in Washington. Her parents describe her as passionate and loving, with deep family ties. The incident occurred shortly before planned travel and key personal milestones, including a trip to Kansas City and an upcoming engagement ring purchase. The tragedy has deeply impacted her family and community, highlighting the personal loss within a broader tragic event.

stories.headline: 2 Killed Near Jewish Museum Were Shot Repeatedly
stories.summary: Two individuals were fatally shot near the Jewish Museum, with the shooting appearing to be targeted. The incident has raised suspicions of a hate crime, especially given Israel's heightened security posture following recent attacks. The alleged shooter, a 31-year-old man, was apprehended at the scene. Authorities are investigating to uncover the motives and circumstances of the attack, which has caused tension and concern.

stories.headline: A Fiery Coach Paces Himself
stories.summary: Jim Irsay, coach of the Pacers, is still striving and demanding results but has learned the importance of collaboration to help manage the challenges he faces. The story highlights his leadership style and approach to team dynamics amid ongoing challenges in professional basketball.

stories.headline: Penny’s End Nears
stories.summary: The cost of making the penny has sky-rocketed in recent years, reaching 3.69 cents per coin, raising questions about the sustainability of keeping the penny in circulation. Discussions continue about potentially retiring the penny as part of broader changes in the U.S. monetary system.

stories.headline: Alberta’s Secession Dreams
stories.summary: A conservative western province of Canada, Alberta, is planning a referendum on a possible long-shot move to break away from the country. This political development reflects ongoing regional discontent and a desire for greater autonomy. The movement faces significant political and legal challenges but marks an important moment in Canadian political dynamics.

stories.headline: Report From Kennedy Delivers A Grim Picture of Youth Health
stories.summary: A report released by Senator Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and health experts details a growing crisis in youth health, citing increases in chronic disease, mental health challenges, and substance abuse. The study criticizes the current public health approach and calls for renewed focus on preventative measures, nutrition, and mental health care access for children and adolescents. The findings have revived public discussions about the health and well-being of the next generation.

stories.headline: Inside Deportation Feud: ‘Keep Him Where He Is’
stories.summary: A political dispute inside the Department of Homeland Security is revealed involving the deportation of Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, exposing tensions about immigration enforcement policies. Documents show officials were divided over his case, which has broader implications for immigration law and enforcement strategies in the U.S. The feud has drawn attention to the conflicting priorities and challenges facing immigration authorities today.

stories.headline: House GOP passes Trump's tax bill
stories.summary: House Republicans passed a multibillion-dollar tax break package, including new rules for food stamps, Medicaid, and provisions related to deportation and defense funding. Despite opposition from Democrats, the House GOP pushed through the 'One Big Beautiful Bill' tied to Trump's priorities, highlighting intense negotiations and political maneuvering in the lead-up to Senate consideration. Trump actively supported the bill, believing it would boost the economy and his political standing.

stories.headline: Active hurricane season warned amid agency cuts
stories.summary: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) projects 13 to 19 named storms in the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season amid staffing and resource shortages. This year's season outlook highlights vulnerabilities due to vacancies and limited resources at NOAA, which is responsible for monitoring hurricanes. The Houston area and other vulnerable regions face increased risks from tropical storms and hurricanes.

stories.headline: Performing arts school cancels Black history musical
stories.summary: Leadership at Houston ISD's Kinder High School for the Performing and Visual Arts canceled the annual Black history musical for the 2025-26 school year. The decision was driven by concerns about educational value and quality, leading to the creation of new performance opportunities such as a fall talent show and Koffee House series instead. The cancellation has sparked community reactions, with calls for transparency and support from the Black Student Union and nonprofit organizations.

stories.headline: County facing $270M budget deficit
stories.summary: Harris County is confronting a $270 million budget shortfall and may need to increase taxes or cut spending for fiscal year 2026, according to Judge Lina Hidalgo. The deficit is the largest seen since Hidalgo was elected in 2018, with potential cuts to nonessential services such as animal shelters and public libraries. Officials also cited rising costs related to indigent defense and inmate care as contributing factors to the deficit.

stories.headline: ICE agents detain several at court
stories.summary: Federal immigration agents detained several people this week at the immigration court in the Earle Cabell Federal Building in downtown Dallas as part of a broader pattern of arrests in multiple cities. Among those detained was Hermenso Arellano-Urena, a Venezuelan man. These actions are part of an intensified federal government process targeting immigration cases previously dismissed.

stories.headline: Trump's big bill clears House
stories.summary: The House of Representatives approved President Donald Trump's major tax cut and immigration legislation, known as the One Big Beautiful Bill, which aims to provide trillions in tax cuts over his first term and shift spending on social safety nets over the next decade. The bill heads to the Senate as GOP leadership hopes to transform the federal government and economy significantly.

stories.headline: This farm produces knowledge: Barnyard lessons include growing food, fighting hunger
stories.summary: Second graders from Reuben Johnson Elementary visited the McKinney Roots donation farm to learn about food origins, food insecurity, and Texas' growing seasons. The farm, run by farmers and volunteers, provides produce to food pantries and soup kitchens. The program connects sustainability education with real-life experience for students in the McKinney Independent School District.

stories.headline: Class prayer time bill moves ahead
stories.summary: A proposal allowing a period for praying and reading religious texts in Texas public schools cleared a key vote and is expected to pass soon, possibly landing on Governor Greg Abbott's desk. The Senate passed the measure with support from House lawmakers, aiming to offer students and staff time outside of instruction to pray if adopted.

stories.headline: No reprieve for Maduro: Chevron’s Venezuela oil license will expire Tuesday, Rubio says
stories.summary: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio announced that Chevron's oil license to operate in Venezuela will expire as scheduled next Tuesday, May 27, despite expectations that it might be extended. The license was part of the Biden administration's effort to encourage political dialogue with the Maduro government while maintaining economic and humanitarian pressures. Rubio signaled this move as a shift in U.S. policy toward Venezuela amid lobbying by oil-industry representatives concerned about their investments.

stories.headline: Rubio: Groups forced to pay Haiti’s gangs won’t be punished
stories.summary: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the House Foreign Affairs Committee highlighting the humanitarian crisis in Haiti caused by armed gangs controlling most of Port-au-Prince and nearby areas. He expressed concern that punishing aid groups forced to pay gang-enforced tolls would harm humanitarian efforts. Rubio clarified that the Trump administration does not intend to punish these organizations for paying gangs to continue aid distribution, emphasizing the grave situation in Haiti.

stories.headline: Three men convicted in murder-for-hire trial over a hit on car designer to stars
stories.summary: Following a long-running feud between rival custom car designers Alex Vega and Rolando "Roly" Ramirez, a Miami federal court jury found Ramirez guilty of directing a murder-for-hire conspiracy involving a hit on Vega in his driveway. Vega survived being shot three times in 2019, and Ramirez was also found guilty of related charges including witness tampering and other offenses. Prosecutor Abie Waxman presented strong arguments, portraying Ramirez and his partner Ali as criminals operating in concert.

stories.headline: ICE agents in Miami find new spot to carry out arrests: Immigration court
stories.summary: Federal agents in plain clothes conducted immigration arrests in Miami's downtown immigration courthouse, surprising many court attendees. About 10 ICE agents, in plain clothes and handcuffed in Spanish, conducted arrests inside the courthouse disguised as court attendees. Department of Homeland Security attorneys moved to drop charges to expedite removal proceedings. The operation caused concern as it involved officers arresting people within court premises during ongoing hearings.

stories.headline: House GOP passes big bill of tax breaks
stories.summary: House Republicans have passed a large multitrillion-dollar tax breaks package despite opposition from some quarters, including Speaker Mike Johnson who challenges certain provisions. The bill aims to advance priorities from former President Donald Trump with concessions and warnings from Trump himself. The House bill passed narrowly with a vote of 215-214 amid a Senate that seems poised to reject the measure, delaying further negotiations and public committee hearings. Criticism included assertions that it benefits the wealthy significantly.

stories.headline: Footprint changes for growing Picklesburgh
stories.summary: Picklesburgh, a festival in Pittsburgh's Downtown area celebrating its 10th anniversary, is expanding its footprint to include more bridges on the Golden Triangle to accommodate growing crowds. The festival has grown in attendance to around 250,000 people with a 27% increase in downtown hotel occupancy attributed to the event. The expansion is expected to bring economic benefits to the local area with a focus on making it a fun patron experience while boosting the local economy.

stories.headline: D.C. Shooting: Suspect Charged With Murder
stories.summary: A man accused of fatally shooting two staff members of the Israeli Embassy in Washington, D.C., has been charged with murder. According to an affidavit, the suspect claimed he did it "for Palestine" and allegedly shouted "Free Palestine" as he was led away after his arrest. The attack has heightened tensions and prompted Israeli missions to increase their security. The incident has also put the Jewish community on edge.

stories.headline: Penn State trustees OK plan
stories.summary: Penn State's Board of Trustees has decided to close seven branch campuses in Western Pennsylvania, including New Kensington, Fayette, and Shenango in Sharon, after the 2026-27 academic year as part of a plan to offer an accessible public education while addressing economic viability in rural communities. This decision was made despite concerns of its impact, with trustees voting 25 in favor and 8 against the closures during a meeting. The closure affects campuses across the state including locations in Central Pennsylvania and York, Wilkes-Barre and Mont Alto in the east.

stories.headline: Religious charter school blocked
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court has deadlocked 4-4 on the issue of allowing the first religious charter school in the country, St. Isidore of Seville Virtual Charter School, effectively blocking its creation. The decision maintains the Oklahoma Supreme Court's ruling that such a school would violate the Constitution's clause to keep religion separate from government. Justice Amy Coney Barrett did not participate, leaving the court evenly divided.
people: St. Isidore of Seville Virtual Charter School

stories.headline: Advocates move to protect George Floyd’s legacy
stories.summary: Five years after George Floyd’s murder, his legacy continues to inspire activism and remembrance. Angela Harrelson, Floyd's aunt, reflects on the impact of his death and the ongoing movement advocating for justice. The murder of Floyd by former police officer Derek Chauvin sparked widespread protests and renewed discourse on police violence and racial injustice, with artists and activists commemorating Floyd's image and life as a symbol of the struggle.

stories.headline: Beyond cemeteries: Places to pay respects
stories.summary: Vanessa Marquette of Syracuse, New York, works to document the history of her relatives' service, including those who fought in World War II and others in the Navy and National Guard. She emphasizes the importance of remembering and sharing the experiences of service members, noting that online research and the internet serve as valuable tools for learning about family military history.

stories.headline: Memorial Day will put parks to biggest test yet
stories.summary: As Memorial Day weekend approaches, national parks and U.S. Forest Service trailheads are expected to see a large influx of visitors seeking clean and well-staffed facilities. However, public lands advocates warn that ongoing widespread layoffs, retirements, and buyouts among park staff may soon result in deteriorating conditions and cause challenges in maintaining parks. There is concern that the Trump administration could use these issues to justify privatizing parks or transferring them to private operators.

stories.headline: City Council approves $104M for I-35 project
stories.summary: The Austin City Council approved $104 million to support the construction of three large decks and two pedestrian bridges over parts of Interstate 35 near downtown Austin. This decision follows weeks of budget conflicts and includes plans to physically reunite historically segregated East Austin with downtown by creating a park-like overpass with walkways and other amenities. The project consists of six park decks and two pedestrian bridges, with the newly approved plan covering three caps and the pedestrian structures, aimed to reduce division caused by the highway.

stories.headline: Texas has QB certainty and not all SEC teams can say that
stories.summary: This sports story highlights Texas football's surety at the quarterback position, which contrasts with several Southeastern Conference (SEC) teams facing uncertainty in the role. The piece discusses how Texas has established stability and reliability with its quarterbacks, a factor that can enhance team performance as the season approaches. The article likely explores the implications of this certainty for Texas's competitive standing in college football.

stories.headline: Texas House joins Senate and OKs own THC ban
stories.summary: The Texas House approved a ban on the sale and consumption of intoxicating hemp products, following similar legislation passed by the Senate. The ban targets consumable hemp products containing more than 0.3% THC, including snack foods, candies, beverages, and smokable products. This move reverses a 2019 law that had established the Texas Industrial Hemp Program allowing for production and sale of industrial hemp products. The bill was passed to curb the proliferation of hemp-derived products with intoxicating effects, and hemp bans will be a legislative priority for 2025.

stories.headline: House passes Trump priorities
stories.summary: The U.S. House passed a significant bill early on May 22 that aligns with President Donald Trump's agenda, though it still requires Senate approval. The legislation includes major changes to Medicaid and SNAP, potentially saving at least $625 billion and affecting over 71 million low-income Americans. However, the bill is controversial as it introduces work requirements for Medicaid expansion and would restrict Medicaid funding for clinics performing abortions and for undocumented children. The future of the bill remains uncertain as it moves to the Senate.

stories.headline: Experts: Gear up for another active season
stories.summary: Experts from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration forecast an above-normal 2025 Atlantic hurricane season with 13 to 19 named storms, 6 to 10 hurricanes, and 3 to 5 major hurricanes. The forecast is influenced by neutral conditions and warmer-than-average ocean temperatures, which can lead to more storms. The season starts June 1 and runs through Nov. 30.

stories.headline: US Mint moves forward with plans to kill the penny
stories.summary: The Trump administration has confirmed the U.S. Mint's decision to stop producing pennies once current supplies run out, due to increased production costs. The penny costs more than its value to make and is underutilized in circulation. About 114 billion pennies are in circulation, but the Treasury expects significant savings from discontinuing production. The mint and Treasury will discuss the matter publicly and seek input before final decisions.

stories.headline: DeSantis signs bill prohibiting golf, hotels in Florida state parks
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill prohibiting the building of golf courses, hotels, and other amenities on state parks in Florida. The law ends a controversial plan and is supported by a broad political spectrum to preserve public land. The Florida Senate unanimously passed the bill, which the governor signed shortly after.

stories.headline: Trump Tax Bill Goes to Senate
stories.summary: President Trump's multitrillion-dollar package of spending and tax cuts is nearing a vote in the Senate. The more than 1,000-page bill passed the House with many Republicans supporting it narrowly, though there are divisions on how to handle climate, energy incentives, and state and local tax deductions. The outcome depends on Senate Republicans' unity as the legislative process advances.

stories.headline: China's Technology Races Forward
stories.summary: China is advancing efforts to build a fortress of economic self-sufficiency by developing cutting-edge technologies rapidly. Despite global geopolitical pressures and U.S. restrictions, Chinese startups like OpenAI and Google rivals continue making strides. The government promotes innovation across strategic sectors to ensure resilience against external constraints and boost domestic capabilities.

stories.headline: Why Project 2025 Has Wild Horse Lobby in a Frenzy
stories.summary: Conservative policy advocates have circulated Project 2025, a policy blueprint that includes proposals to cull Western wild horse populations. The plan has alarmed animal welfare groups and sparked controversy due to its call for arms against wild horses. The debate centers on ecological, economic, and cultural impacts of managing wild horse populations in public lands.

stories.headline: Stop Making Cents
stories.summary: The U.S. Treasury will stop producing pennies starting next year, an effort projected to save $56 million annually. Currently, nearly 4 cents are spent to manufacture each penny. This decision reflects changing economics around currency production and may reshape how low-value cash transactions are handled in the economy.

stories.headline: Antitrust Cops Say Big Funds Can Hinder Competition
stories.summary: Federal antitrust officials are scrutinizing large institutional investors who hold significant stakes in competing companies. Their influence could reduce competition across markets. The Federal Trade Commission has filed lawsuits targeting major asset managers like BlackRock, State Street, and Vanguard to investigate and curb potentially anti-competitive behavior linked to common ownership in multiple competing firms.

stories.headline: D.C. Ambush Ended Couple's Love Story
stories.summary: An ambush in Washington D.C. ended the love story of Israeli Embassy employees Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Milgrim. After a canceled flight, the couple attended the Capital Jewish Museum event just hours before the attack. The assailants targeted the embassy staffers, killing Lischinsky. The incident highlights ongoing violence and tensions involving the state of Israel and exposes the dangers faced by diplomats abroad.

stories.headline: U.S. Bars Harvard's Foreign Students
stories.summary: The U.S. government has barred Harvard University from enrolling foreign students, escalating the ongoing pressure campaign against the university. The move is part of a broader effort tied to concerns about diversity, equity, and alleged anti-American activities on campus. Harvard has pulled billions in funding and now faces threats of tax-exempt status revocation as the dispute continues to undermine relations between the university and the federal government.

stories.headline: Schurr will not be retried for murder, says prosecutor
stories.summary: Former Grand Rapids police officer Christopher Schurr will not face a retrial for the second-degree murder of Patrick Lyoya following a mistrial when jurors failed to reach a unanimous verdict. Prosecutor Chris Becker cites the difficulty in obtaining 12 unanimous votes as the reason behind the decision. The incident involved the shooting of Lyoya, a Black motorist, after a traffic stop in April 2022. Schurr's lead counsel supports the decision, while Lyoya's family expresses heartbreak over recent related trials.

stories.headline: Michigan marijuana regulators consider new testing transparency
stories.summary: Michigan regulators are proposing a change to increase transparency in marijuana testing, allowing consumers to know if their product failed safety testing and underwent a decontamination process called "remediation." The Cannabis Regulatory Agency has resisted forced labeling but now faces criticism for not adequately informing customers about remediation methods and potential residual toxins. Industry voices argue that better disclosure is needed to protect consumers and ensure safety.

stories.headline: Young American men are among the loneliest
stories.summary: A Gallup poll finds that young American men, particularly those aged 15 to 34, report higher levels of loneliness than their female counterparts and compared to men in other wealthy countries. The study highlights a severe public health threat as loneliness has been linked to increased risks for numerous health problems. Experts emphasize understanding loneliness as a social challenge that has worsened during the pandemic and requires public attention.

stories.headline: Trump’s tax, policy bill advances
stories.summary: Iowa’s 4 GOP U.S. House members backed a bill that moves President Donald Trump’s budget forward, including significant tax cuts and cuts to Medicaid and the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, raising the deficit. The bill also aims to eliminate taxes on workers' tips and overtime, key campaign promises from Trump. Democrats criticize the bill, saying it hurts Americans relying on social safety nets like Medicaid and SNAP. The legislation is expected to add $3.3 trillion to the deficit over 10 years and increase the number of people without health insurance by at least 7.6 million.

stories.headline: Immigrant from Iowa deported to Africa
stories.summary: Kyaw Mya, a longtime Iowa resident and registered sex offender originally from Burma, was deported to South Sudan following a federal judge ruling that the deportation violated a court order. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement arrested him in February and removed him along with seven other immigrants. The Department of Homeland Security faced criticism for not properly informing authorities of the flight or giving sufficient time for legal concerns to be addressed. Massachusetts federal judge ruled the flight violated his earlier order. DHS spokesperson emphasized focusing on victimized Americans rather than circumstances of deportations.

stories.headline: Des Moines family mourns after blaze
stories.summary: A tragic fire on May 20 destroyed the home of Yotamu Nyedetse in Des Moines, killing seven family members including elderly, children, and relatives. Nyedetse and others were asleep at the time and only escaped by alerting the family. The community is mourning the loss and the family has launched a GoFundMe page seeking $100,000 to help with funeral costs, housing, nutrition, and a new wheelchair for survivor Niyintwaye Fidel.

stories.headline: Loving Bay Area’s most diverse neighborhood
stories.summary: A 10-block area in Oakland, situated between East 19th Street and 20th Avenue, is recognized as the Bay Area's most racially diverse neighborhood. Despite gentrification pressures, this community maintains its unique character with a vibrant mix of residents and cultures. The article highlights the social dynamics and cultural richness of the neighborhood as it faces ongoing changes.

stories.headline: Senate guts state climate policy
stories.summary: The Senate has struck down California's signature climate change policy which mandated a transition to electric vehicles by 2035, with a close 51-44 vote. Governor Gavin Newsom has pledged to sue the federal government to maintain the state's emission standards. While most Democrats opposed revoking the electric vehicle mandate, a few supported it alongside some Republicans. The move signals a rollback of California's strict environmental policies that exceed federal regulations.

stories.headline: Trump tax bill to hit California hard
stories.summary: Legislation approved by the House would significantly impact California by slashing health care spending and limiting the state’s ability to regulate artificial intelligence. The bill, part of Donald Trump's second term, includes cuts to food stamps, Medicaid, and the clean energy tax break. An all-night House session was required to pass the bill, with opposition primarily from Democrats and some Republicans. The consequences for California's healthcare and regulation powers are expected to be severe.

stories.headline: UCSF brain injury work may transform concussion care
stories.summary: Neurologists at UCSF have developed a new scale for assessing brain trauma damage that could revolutionize concussion treatment. This scale helps doctors better diagnose and care for patients with mild to severe injuries, including those in near-death coma states. The Glasgow Coma Scale, used for over 50 years, is now supplemented by this novel approach to provide detailed patient assessments and improve treatment outcomes.

stories.headline: Melting snowpack impacting fire risk
stories.summary: The western U.S. is experiencing a prolonged drought with diminished snowpack, increasing wildfire risks in the upcoming months. Above-normal temperatures and reduced precipitation have led to significant snowpack depletion, particularly in basins critical for seasonal water supply. Regional drought coordinators caution that these conditions combined with warm and dry weather patterns are heightening fire hazards for the season.

stories.headline: Edison’s rate hike plan draws anger
stories.summary: Southern California Edison is seeking a 10% rate increase to cover wildfire mitigation and infrastructure costs, sparking backlash from ratepayers and survivors of recent wildfires. Survivors who lost homes in historic wildfires express anger over the added financial burden, while Edison defends the rate increase as necessary for safety improvements. The debate intensifies as regulators and consumer advocates weigh the fairness of the proposed hikes.

stories.headline: Divided House passes Trump’s megabill
stories.summary: The House passed a landmark legislation that would rewrite the tax code, boost funding for defense and border security, and revamp tax rules including renewing 2017 tax cuts. Despite opposition from some Senate Republicans, the bill titled 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act,' aims to eliminate taxes on tips and overtime, provide a new tax deduction for seniors, and increase spending on healthcare and food stamps.

stories.headline: Split Supreme Court blocks first religious charter school
stories.summary: The Supreme Court blocked a new Oklahoma charter school from receiving state funding, ruling that its constitution does not allow funding for religious or church-based schools. The court's decision reflects concerns about funding schools run by religious groups and bars exclusion of religious entities from public funding programs. The ruling has broader implications for state vouchers and subsidies for religiously affiliated private schools.

stories.headline: She’s only 11 — and she’s wrapped up community college
stories.summary: Alisa Perales will graduate with associate degrees from Crafton Hills College, making her one of the youngest graduates in California history. Starting college at a very young age, Alisa surprised her parents and professors with her academic achievements, earning high grades and excelling in multiple sciences and mathematics, highlighting her extraordinary talent and drive.

stories.headline: State rule on gas-only cars is revoked
stories.summary: The U.S. Senate voted to revoke California's plan to ban the sale of new vehicles that run only on fossil fuels, overturning a Biden-era waiver that enabled California and Democratic-led states to enact zero-emission vehicle mandates. This move challenges California's clean car policies, which were designed to reduce pollution and promote electric vehicles, and is expected to impact future emission standards and automotive industry regulations.

stories.headline: Farewell to an icon
stories.summary: Jim Irsay, the owner of the Indianapolis Colts and noted philanthropist, has died peacefully in his sleep at the age of 65. He transformed the Colts from a team of irrelevancy into a football city and was deeply committed to his family and community. His daughters are expected to take over ownership of the team.

stories.headline: Generous but imperfect, Irsay made Indy better
stories.summary: Colts owner Jim Irsay was remembered as a gentle, generous, and imperfect man who made public his personal struggles and mistakes. His death on May 21 at age 65 was mourned deeply in Indianapolis, with many acknowledging the city is less without him, comparing his loss to that of an owner who loved his players like his own family.

stories.headline: Arrests inside immigration court sparking fear in city
stories.summary: Federal agents arrested several people inside Chicago's immigration court over the past two days as part of an ongoing enforcement effort that sources link to presidential policies. Many agents wore badges or U.S. immigration officer identification. Witnesses report that three individuals were taken into custody amid plainclothes and uniformed officers early Wednesday afternoon. Their lawyer, Essam Abdallah, states the clients are immigrants who had been in the court.

stories.headline: Calumet and Chicago rivers 'pretty clean,' report shows
stories.summary: A report on the Chicago River and Calumet River's water quality shows that despite some compromised immune systems making some members vulnerable, overall conditions remain good or low-caution. Coaches from the year-round rowing team of breast cancer survivors are optimistic about storm and lightening forecasts and the bacteria levels monitored along the rivers, indicating it is safe to head out during the summer months.

stories.headline: 'Act of cowardice'
stories.summary: A Chicago man, Elias Rodriguez, has been charged in the fatal shooting of two Israeli Embassy workers in Washington, D.C. The incident occurred amid social media outrage over ongoing Gaza bombings. Rodriguez allegedly admitted to the shooting, claiming he 'did it for Palestine.' The FBI cordoned off his North Side apartment following the incident. The victims, Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky, were a couple close to getting engaged. Family members mourn their loss and reflect on their plans.

stories.headline: A Paul Simon 'celebration'
stories.summary: A heavy concert series celebrating Paul Simon's music is set to take place at the city's Symphony Center, bringing fans together for a tribute to the legendary artist.

stories.headline: Blackhawks get their guy
stories.summary: The Chicago Blackhawks have landed Jeff Blashill as the new head coach to lead their rebuilding efforts in the upcoming season.

stories.headline: Suspect: ‘I did it for Palestine, I did it for Gaza’
stories.summary: Elias Rodriguez, accused of fatally shooting two staff members outside the Israeli Embassy in Washington, declared that he acted in support of Palestine and Gaza. The incident, classified as a targeted act of terror, followed a broader conflict involving Israel and Hamas in the Middle East. Rodriguez faces charges of murder and other crimes but did not enter a plea at his initial court appearance. The attack heightened tensions and raised concerns about domestic security and influence from international conflicts.

stories.headline: Decatur man charged for bomb threats
stories.summary: A Decatur man faces federal charges after allegedly sending text messages threatening to detonate a bomb at Bangor International Airport in Maine. The FBI affidavit reveals that Robert Tyler Wicks is charged with conveying false and misleading information about an explosive device. The messages targeted American Airlines employees and included personal details, leading to investigations and multiple agencies' involvement. Security officials took significant measures following the incident to prevent any potential threat.

stories.headline: ‘The greatest end’
stories.summary: Elise Robinson's pet Volta ball python, which recently died at the age of 32 from a corn snake bite, was cherished as a transformative companion throughout its life span. She expressed her appreciation for the snake's longevity and the special bond they shared. Robinson named the snake 'Jane Goodall' after the famous primatologist, admiring its shy and hunger-strike behaviors. The story reflects on the meaningful relationship between pet and owner and the significant years they spent together.

stories.headline: $1 million allocated for trail
stories.summary: State Senator Arthur Orr of Decatur has allocated $1 million in state funding for a trail on the south side of Alabama 67/Point Mallard Parkway from the Country Club Road intersection to the Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge's visitor center. This funding was approved during the spring session's general budget for fiscal 2026 and aims to improve accessibility of the refuge for Decatur residents and visitors. Council President Jacob Ladner highlighted that the trail project, which may require additional funding, is part of a larger effort to enhance outdoor recreation and connectivity in the area.

stories.headline: Kohberger defense team seeks delay of murder trial
stories.summary: Attorneys for Bryan Kohberger, charged with killing four University of Idaho students, have requested the presiding judge to postpone the long-awaited murder trial scheduled for late July. The defense filed a request to delay jury selection to provide enough time for evidence review and to investigate the source of NBC's 'Dateline' episode information. Kohberger is charged with four counts of first-degree murder in connection with the November 2022 university homicides, with prosecutors seeking the death penalty if convicted.

stories.headline: Speed bumps pop up 'like dandelions' in Northwest Boise
stories.summary: Numerous temporary speed bumps have been installed across several roads in Northwest Boise to reduce traffic speed and improve safety. The project, managed by the Ada County Highway District, includes road widenings, U-turns, medians, crosswalks, and multi-use pathways. While some community members praised the effort for reducing traffic, others expressed concerns over increased noise and inconvenience, highlighting divided public opinion on the changes.

stories.headline: Boise faces $10M negligence claim after Greenbelt crash
stories.summary: The family of a woman who died from a traumatic brain injury after a bike crash on Boise Greenbelt has filed a tort claim against the city, alleging negligence in maintaining the pathway. The claim centers on the presence of numerous bumps and spray-painted markings, which the city was aware of but did not resolve. Tort claims act as a precursor to lawsuits, and this claim seeks $10 million in damages from the city, highlighting concerns over pathway safety.

stories.headline: Caldwell deals with growth as developer plans 1,000 homes
stories.summary: The city of Caldwell is preparing for significant growth as developer Toll Brothers plans a residential development of over 1,000 homes near Vallivue Middle School. The project, approved recently for a 282-acre subdivision, is expected to increase housing density and bring congestion concerns about traffic, schools, and taxes. Residents expressed mixed reactions, citing worries about infrastructure challenges while some welcomed the new housing opportunities.

stories.headline: State’s GOP lawmakers help House OK tax cuts
stories.summary: A narrowly passed tax cut bill in the U.S. House of Representatives faces rocky road ahead in the Senate, with several Republican senators indicating they may not support the bill. Key Arizona GOP senators have opposed the bill, saying it aids the wealthy at the expense of the poor and working families. Despite this, House Republicans jammed the bill through, which includes permanent extensions of President Donald Trump's 2017 tax cuts and increased spending on Medicaid services. The House voted to pass a sizeable 1,100-page bill that impacts domestic agenda, but the Senate's approval remains uncertain.

stories.headline: AZ Health Department rings cannabis testing alarm bells
stories.summary: The Arizona Health Department is threatening to revoke the license of a marijuana testing company and fined another for alleged violations that may endanger consumers by allowing products with less THC than advertised or containing harmful contaminants. The department cited issues related to anti-nepotism laws and noted the firm's non-compliance with testing standards, resulting in inaccurate potency and contaminant readings. The implicated company, Florida-based Kaycha Labs, is under scrutiny in several states including Arizona, following repeated failure in compliance and accuracy in testing procedures.

stories.headline: Abortion providers challenge more laws
stories.summary: Abortion providers and advocates filed a comprehensive lawsuit targeting better than a dozen laws in Arizona they claim restrict access to health care and are unconstitutional following a 2024 voter-approved amendment. The lawsuit focuses on laws and regulations that providers say create unnecessary and burdensome barriers to abortion access. These include requirements for two in-person doctor visits, a 24-hour waiting period, restrictions on abortions for specific reasons, and heightened reporting and enforcement measures. Plaintiffs include doctors and the Arizona Medical Association, supported by civil liberties groups and a law firm filing in Maricopa County.

stories.headline: Owner of private jet registered in Alaska killed in San Diego crash
stories.summary: A private jet registered in Alaska crashed near San Diego, claiming the lives of all six people on board, including the registered owner David Shapiro, a 42-year-old pilot. The Cessna S550 jet went down during foggy weather conditions in a residential area. Authorities reported no ground casualties. The plane was registered to California talent agency, with Shapiro as a co-founder of a music talent group.

stories.headline: Bill’s work requirements may transform Medicaid, food aid
stories.summary: A new U.S. social safety net bill backed by President Donald Trump proposes work requirements for low-income adults to qualify for Medicaid health insurance and food assistance. The bill aims to cut costs and reduce dependency, but it has sparked debate about potential negative impacts on tens of thousands of Alaskans and the need for personal responsibility. Supporters argue the bill will save money and encourage accountability.

stories.headline: ASD leaders worry over potential budget veto
stories.summary: Administrators and school board members of the Anchorage School District express concern about a possible veto by Governor Mike Dunleavy of a $180 million increase to Alaska's education spending. The veto comes days after lawmakers overrode the governor's veto, and district officials emphasize the potential negative impact on inflation-adjusted funding and education programs if the veto is enacted.

stories.headline: City settles with family of girl killed by APD for $2.1M
stories.summary: The Municipality of Anchorage and the family of a 16-year-old girl shot and killed by police last year have settled all civil claims for $2.1 million. The death of Easter Leafa drew attention to police use-of-force policies after a series of fatal shootings. Leafa was shot on Aug. 13 after police confronted her in an East Anchorage apartment following a warning to drop a knife. The officers involved were cleared, and the settlement resolves claims against both family and municipal officials.

stories.headline: Palm Beach International planning expansion as private flights surge
stories.summary: Palm Beach International Airport is planning a major expansion, including extending its south runway, to manage the increase in private air traffic since the COVID-19 pandemic. Laura Beebe, director of the Palm Beach County Department of Airports, highlighted the need to accommodate the rising arrivals and departures as affluent travelers frequent the airport more.

stories.headline: Forecasters look for clues as hurricane season nears
stories.summary: NOAA predicts 13 to 19 named storms and 3 to 5 major hurricanes for the upcoming hurricane season. Meteorologist Andy Hazelton explains that the Atlantic basin’s complex climate patterns suggest the season could be more active than average. The forecast is based on analyses of storm activity, energy accumulation, and past seasons, with caution urged for preparedness.

stories.headline: 2 Israeli Embassy staffers killed in DC
stories.summary: Two Israeli Embassy staff members, Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Lynn Milgrim, were fatally shot in Washington DC after attending an event at the Capital Jewish Museum. The tragedy is seen as a shocking act of violence, with the American Jewish Committee CEO describing it as motivated by hate against the Jewish people. Officials thanked President Donald Trump, DC Mayor Muriel Bowser, and law enforcement for their swift support.

stories.headline: Overdose prompts cannabis warning
stories.summary: Tompkins County Whole Health officials warned residents about the dangers of consuming unlicensed cannabis products such as edibles and vapes after a student nearly died from an unforeseen overdose in Dryden. The Dryden Central School District reported that a student collapsed after inhaling from what was believed to be a cannabis vape. The student was treated with opioid overdose reversal medication and survived. Lab tests confirmed the device contained fentanyl, a potent opioid with a lethal dose smaller than a grain of rice, highlighting the risks of illicit cannabis products.

stories.headline: Advocates raise alarm over SAVE Act
stories.summary: Senate Democrats and voting rights advocates are pushing to defeat the GOP's Safeguard American Voter Eligibility Act (SAVE Act) because they say it would disenfranchise Native American voters, particularly those living on tribal lands or remote areas. The bill would require voters to show proof of citizenship in person for federal elections, which could create significant hurdles as these voters often have to travel long distances to register. Advocates claim the law contains numerous challenges for Native Americans, including excluding tribal cards without birthplaces as valid identification.

stories.headline: 'Tush Push' play survives league vote
stories.summary: The controversial 'Tush Push' play has survived a critical vote within the sports league, allowing it to continue in gameplay. This decision comes amid debates on the play's fairness and impact on the game. Fans and players alike have expressed varying opinions, but the league's ruling maintains the play's place in the upcoming season.

stories.headline: Most sunscreens fall short, report finds
stories.summary: A new report from the Environmental Working Group evaluated over 2,200 sunscreen products sold in U.S. stores and found that fewer than 500 effectively protect against UV rays. The report highlights that many sunscreen products fall short due to misleading claims, outdated formulas, and inclusion of potentially harmful ingredients such as allergens, hormone disruptors, and carcinogens. Despite federal sunscreen rules remaining largely unchanged since 1999, consumers are cautioned to navigate sunscreen products carefully due to these safety and efficacy concerns.

stories.headline: Hospital supplies face tariff crunch
stories.summary: Medical supply companies and health systems, including HCMC in Minneapolis, are facing rising costs due to newly imposed global trade tariffs on essential medical items like gloves. The tariffs threaten to increase prices and cause shortages of critical hospital supplies, impacting medical care quality. Officials and suppliers are concerned about the financial and operational strains caused by trade tensions involving countries such as Thailand.

stories.headline: As first lady, she left an indelible mark
stories.summary: Rudy Perpich’s wife, Lola Perpich, who passed away at age 94, was remembered for her strong partnership with the former governor of Minnesota and her influential role as first lady. Known for her commitment to family and public service, she was admired for her support to her husband and her own legacy in Minnesota politics and society.

stories.headline: Trump cuts Harvard's foreign enrollment
stories.summary: The Trump administration revoked Harvard University’s ability to enroll international students amid ongoing battles over Ivy League schools’ foreign student populations. The Department of Homeland Security announced this drastic move citing concerns over fake campuses for foreign students and coordination with foreign communist groups, significantly affecting Harvard's international enrollment policies.

stories.headline: Trump's tax bill moves on to Senate
stories.summary: House Republicans approved President Donald Trump's tax reform bill, which includes tax cuts for corporations and individuals, as well as new spending increases. The legislation aims to transform the federal government and economy but has raised concerns about the national debt and long-term economic impact. The bill now awaits Senate consideration after a contentious legislative process.

stories.headline: A blow for public religious schools
stories.summary: The Supreme Court rejected a plan allowing Oklahoma to use public funds to support the nation's first religious charter school, which would teach a curriculum infused by Catholic doctrine. This decision blocks similar proposals and maintains separation between public funding and religious instruction, despite divided opinions and ongoing debates about the scope of the First Amendment.

stories.headline: A vow to continue police reforms
stories.summary: Minneapolis officials have vowed to persist with police reform efforts despite the Justice Department's request to dissolve the Police Department's consent decree. Mayor Jacob Frey and City Council leadership plan to enact changes independently, emphasizing accountability even without federal enforcement. City leaders and experts underline the importance of maintaining accountability amid concerns about losing federal oversight.

stories.headline: Hutchinson back from injury with grateful heart
stories.summary: Aidan Hutchinson has fully recovered from a gruesome leg injury that sidelined him for seven months. His injury occurred during a promising start to the season, but after intensive recovery, he is now ready to return to full-team football workouts with the Allen Park Lions. Hutchinson credits his faith and gratitude as key to overcoming the physical and emotional challenges of his injury.

stories.headline: U.S. Mint: No more pennies
stories.summary: The U.S. Mint has stopped producing pennies as part of an effort to cut costs and improve efficiency. By ending penny production, the Treasury aims to save millions annually due to reduced material costs. The decision aligns with broader efforts to modernize currency and address declining penny usage. The move follows President Donald Trump's announcement of the end of the penny production in February 2025, marking a significant change in U.S. currency.

stories.headline: Autos rejoice with Calif. rules under siege
stories.summary: The auto industry celebrated a move by Congress to cancel California emissions standards, which required aggressive shifts to electric vehicles. The decision provides relief to automakers who had to adhere to stricter regulations stronger than consumer demand. However, the news comes amid signs of turbulence for Michigan's auto sector due to uncertainties from California regulations and international competition, all against the backdrop of ongoing political targeting of President Trump's policies.

stories.headline: No retrial in fatal Mich. arrest; family ‘very disappointed’
stories.summary: Kent County Prosecutor Chris Becker announced there will be no retrial for Grand Rapids police officer Christopher Schurr who was involved in the April 2022 shooting of Patrick Lyoya. The decision came after the family sought a new trial following a hung jury earlier in the month. Becker stated there was no basis to retry the case, eliciting disappointment from Lyoya's family and raising concerns about justice and accountability in the case.

stories.headline: As a master of courses, he's finding a following
stories.summary: Sean Melia, a 41-year-old from Charlestown, has turned his passion for golf into a career by playing all 350-ish golf courses in Massachusetts. After leaving education due to burnout, Melia embraced this unique pursuit, creating a documentary about Baystate Golf and becoming a recognized figure in the golf community. He recently played New England Country Club, aiming to be the first to complete all courses.

stories.headline: Move could open up liquor licenses for cities
stories.summary: Massachusetts Senate approved a $61 million proposal to give local governments more power to issue liquor licenses, after the House resisted relinquishing authority. The bill aims to address issues with license distribution and local regulations, allowing cities and towns to grant licenses to restaurants and other businesses beyond existing caps, helping municipalities manage licenses more flexibly.

stories.headline: Mass. biggest loser on cuts to science grants
stories.summary: Massachusetts has lost more National Science Foundation money for science, math, and engineering research than any other state this year, with a $249 million decline since the start of the Trump administration. The NSF cut 251 grants to Massachusetts institutions compared to the prior year, significantly impacting research projects. The public attention has focused on the Health and Human Services department encompassing the National Institute of Health as well.

stories.headline: Harvard's foreign students targeted
stories.summary: The Trump administration revoked Harvard University's ability to enroll foreign students, a damaging step aligning with President Trump's worldview. The move disrupts futures of thousands of students amid incoming freshman confirmations and raises questions about the legality and future of foreign student enrollment at Harvard. This follows recent tensions between Harvard and the federal government over an extraordinary records request.

stories.headline: Razor-thin margin enough for GOP on bill
stories.summary: The House narrowly passed a wide-ranging bill to deliver President Trump's domestic agenda after Speaker Mike Johnson overcame several Republican mini-rebellions. The legislation slashes taxes and spending, shifting to the Senate amid efforts to muscle it through despite unified Democratic opposition. The bill cuts Medicaid and food assistance, aiming for long-term deficit reduction and government borrowing limits.

stories.headline: Ex-Philly cop guilty of voluntary manslaughter
stories.summary: A jury found Mark Dial guilty of voluntary manslaughter and related crimes for recklessly shooting Eddie Irizarry in 2023. Dial was acquitted of a murder charge but convicted of recklessly endangering another person and possessing an instrument of crime. The incident occurred when officers encountered Irizarry; Dial shot him after a tense confrontation. The jury deliberated over eight hours before reaching the verdict.

stories.headline: Supreme Court tie vote dooms the creation of religious charter school
stories.summary: The Supreme Court deadlocked 4-4 on a case that could have allowed the creation of a Catholic charter school in Oklahoma. The ruling means the state law banning such schools remains in effect. The case tested constitutional questions about funding religious institutions in public education. With only eight justices voting, the tie leaves the lower court ruling intact against the school's creation.

stories.headline: Feds charge man in D.C. slayings
stories.summary: Authorities charged a man accused of fatally shooting two staff members of the Israeli Embassy in Washington during a terrorist event. The suspect shouted "Free Palestine" upon arrest and faces multiple federal charges. The killings targeted the Jewish community and are being investigated as terrorism. Officials are continuing their investigation into the incident and the suspect's role.

stories.headline: Swing-district Republicans playing defense on Trump's budget bill
stories.summary: Pennsylvania representatives in the U.S. House are split largely along party lines on President Trump's budget bill. The bill passed by a vote of 215-214, with mostly Republicans supporting and Democrats opposing. Democrats call the bill a betrayal of the middle class, citing cuts to social programs and increased defense spending. Swing-district Republicans face pressure balancing constituent interests and party loyalty.

stories.headline: DHS to Harvard: No more foreign students
stories.summary: The Trump administration revoked Harvard University's ability to enroll international students amid escalating tensions with China. Current foreign students must leave or transfer. The Department of Homeland Security cited allowing "anti-American, pro-terrorist agitators" and links to the Chinese Communist Party as reasons. Harvard enrolls about 6,800 foreign students and risks significant disruption to its academic community and research mission.

stories.headline: Home-Grown Horror: Chicagoan Elias Rodriguez Charged with Murdering Couple Outside Jewish Museum in D.C.
stories.summary: Elias Rodriguez, a Chicago resident, has been charged with the murder of a couple outside a Jewish museum in Washington, D.C. Rodriguez allegedly committed the act motivated by political reasons, stating 'I did it for Palestine, I did it for Gaza.' Federal agents are currently investigating, and have been collecting evidence from Rodriguez's apartment in Albany Park. The victims have been identified as Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky.

stories.headline: Mammoth spending bill passes House vote
stories.summary: House Republicans approved President Donald Trump’s sprawling tax and immigration agenda that includes trillions of dollars in new campaigns alongside hikes on taxes on tips, overtime wages, and hundreds of billions of dollars in new spending. The legislation, which passed after marathon talks, carries a hefty price tag and now heads to Senate where the price tag may be a pitfall.

stories.headline: Martin’s failure shows Trump’s hold has limits
stories.summary: Ed Martin's failed nomination as U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia reveals cracks in President Trump's influence, especially with Senate Republicans. Despite Trump's backing, Martin’s nomination was blocked due to opposition from individuals wary of his alignment with the administration. The episode shows the limits of Trump's political hold even amid strong loyalty within his ranks.

stories.headline: DHS yanks Harvard’s admission of foreign students
stories.summary: The Department of Homeland Security revoked Harvard University’s certification to admit foreign students amid a crackdown on alleged illegal immigration involving ‘anti-American, pro-terrorist’ foreign students. The agency ordered Harvard to terminate programs that allow foreign students to attend and physically assault individuals, citing the Chinese Communist Party’s influence. This move is part of a broader effort to control immigration and national security.

stories.headline: Deadlocked justices block first religious public school
stories.summary: The Supreme Court deadlocked 4-4 in a case concerning the constitutionality of a newly opened religious charter school, preventing a ruling on the fine line between church and state in public education. The decision maintains the status quo as the Court awaits the appointment of a new justice to break the tie. The ruling affects a Catholic institution in Oklahoma that would have reshaped American education and challenged church-state boundaries.

stories.headline: Death, shock at Jewish museum
stories.summary: Two Israeli Embassy staffers were shot and killed in downtown Washington during a diplomatic reception, sending shock waves through the city and reverberating worldwide. The suspect, a Chicago man who supported the Palestinian cause, was charged with two counts of first-degree murder and murder of foreign officials. The victims, Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Lynn Milgrim, were engaged and attended the event as part of a diplomatic function. The incident has led to increased surveillance and investigations are ongoing.

stories.headline: House GOP passes 'big, beautiful' budget bill
stories.summary: President Donald Trump and House Speaker Mike Johnson won as the Republican-controlled House passed 'The One, Big, Beautiful Bill,' a $215-214 vote mainly along party lines. The bill includes tax incentives and Medicaid program proposals, with major opposition from Democrats.

stories.headline: Two restaurant managers lauded for saving man's life
stories.summary: Becky Pennington and Stephanie Poole, restaurant managers at Texas Roadhouse, responded quickly when a customer collapsed in the parking lot. They performed lifesaving actions including automated external defibrillator use until emergency personnel arrived.

stories.headline: Bodycam video released in fatal York Rd. shooting
stories.summary: The Baltimore Police Department released body camera footage related to the shooting death of a 26-year-old man, Maj. Marc Howell, following an encounter with police on York Road on May 12. The footage shows the moments leading up to and including the incident. Police officers involved are under investigation.

stories.headline: OT, vacancies may cost city $150M in '25
stories.summary: Baltimore city leaders warn that overtime and vacancies, driven by high vacancy rates in city agencies, may cost the city up to $150 million in overtime expenses by 2025. The city spent $89.5 million on overtime in 2023 and $139 million in 2024. Firefighter vacancies contribute significantly to overtime costs.

stories.headline: Maryland Democrats energized by new leader
stories.summary: Kevin Pittman is expected to succeed Staurt Pittman as the leader of Maryland Democrats in the House of Delegates. The change is part of efforts by Democrats to strengthen their position against Republican policies and inspire voter turnout in the state.

stories.headline: 'Taking the leap'
stories.summary: Kermit the Frog speaks at University of Maryland College Park graduation, offering wisdom about finding your people and making connections during the commencement speech.

stories.headline: Family mourns Carissa Perryman, who was shot in KC alley
stories.summary: Carissa Perryman, a 29-year-old Kansas City woman, was fatally shot in an alley in mid-May. She was remembered as a loving mother, caretaker, and beloved by her family and friends. Perryman was described as open and caring, and her loss has deeply affected her loved ones who are trying to cope with the tragedy. Police report that the incident is under active investigation. The shooting occurred following an altercation involving a neighboring couple.

stories.headline: ScriptPro announces layoffs amid Trump tariffs
stories.summary: ScriptPro, a pharmacy robotics and automation company based in Mission, announced mass layoffs last week citing financial concerns and challenges arising from tariffs imposed by the Trump administration. The company offered voluntary separation packages to affected employees. The layoffs follow a national emergency declaration and increased tariffs on imported goods, affecting various industries. ScriptPro, employing around 500 people, stated the importance of adjusting to fast-moving market changes.

stories.headline: Johnson County woman killed in D.C. shooting
stories.summary: Two Israeli Embassy staff members, Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky, were shot dead near the Capital Jewish Museum in Washington, D.C., in a suspected anti-Semitic attack by a gunman who shouted 'free Palestine.' Milgrim was a Kansas native and a devoted member of the Jewish community. Authorities are investigating the incident as a deeply disturbing anti-Semitic attack, with local Jewish leaders mourning the loss and emphasizing Milgrim's integrity and purpose.

stories.headline: DNR to holiday travelers: Prepare for shock Up North
stories.summary: The Michigan Department of Natural Resources warns holiday travelers heading Up North about significant tree debris and damage caused by a recent deadly spring ice storm. The storm affected over 3 million acres, damaging state parks, forests, and recreation areas. Visitors should expect cleared trails but also some still blocked by fallen trees.

stories.headline: Michigan facing Medicaid changes
stories.summary: The U.S. House of Representatives passed sweeping legislation affecting Medicaid coverage for low-income adults in Michigan. The bill extends and increases tax cuts, removes many environmental subsidies, and revises SNAP and EV programs, potentially impacting many residents. The bill awaits Senate reconsideration and may see changes before final approval by President Donald Trump.

stories.headline: Prosecutor: No retrial for ex-police officer
stories.summary: A west Michigan prosecutor announced no retrial for former Grand Rapids Police Officer Christopher Schurr, who was charged in the 2022 shooting death of Patrick Lyoya. Despite a mistrial, the prosecutor stated there was no conviction from the initial trial and that Schurr will not face any lesser charges related to the second-degree murder charge. The Lyoya family expressed disappointment with the decision.

stories.headline: State Department officials deny internal rift over Trump’s decision to lift Syria sanctions
stories.summary: Top U.S. State Department officials denied reports of internal conflict regarding President Trump's 2025 lifting of economic sanctions on Syria. Michael Anton, policy planning chief, emphasized ongoing alignment on U.S.-Syria policy and dismissed claims of discord within the administration.

stories.headline: Noem boots Harvard from foreign student host ‘privilege’
