stories.summary: South Dakota Governor Kristi Noem moved to decertify Harvard University from its foreign student program, citing concerns over the accelerating war of words between the Trump administration and the school. Noem criticized Harvard for fostering alleged anti-Semitism and coordinating with the Chinese Communist Party.

stories.headline: Terror links probed in embassy staffers’ deaths
stories.summary: Investigations are ongoing into possible terror connections surrounding the deaths of two Israeli Embassy staff members, Yaron Lischinsky and Sarah Milgrim. A suspect has been arrested for shootings linked to pro-Hamas rhetoric, as officials uncover details of the violent incident and its aftermath.

stories.headline: Biden doctor, aides to face House query on fitness
stories.summary: House lawmakers requested interviews with President Biden's doctor and aides about concerns over his mental health and potential pardons. The Oversight Committee cited reports about Biden's cognitive challenges and sudden diagnosis of prostate cancer as part of their inquiry into his fitness for office.

stories.headline: Trump’s ‘big, beautiful bill’ clears House by one vote
stories.summary: The House passed President Trump's 'big, beautiful bill' containing tax cuts, border funds, and defense spending, advancing to the Senate amid Republican efforts to adjust Medicaid spending and overcome filibuster hurdles. House Speaker Mike Johnson pushed the legislation forward with a narrow one-vote margin.

stories.headline: Deadlocked ruling blocks nation’s first religious charter school
stories.summary: The Supreme Court deadlocked 4-4 on a case involving the exclusion of St. Isidore of Seville Catholic Virtual School from Oklahoma's charter school program. The ruling leaves the lower court’s decision and blocking intact, sparking debate over religious school access and civil liberties involving the American Civil Liberties Union.

stories.headline: House passes cuts to Medicaid
stories.summary: The U.S. House passed a Republican bill aimed at cutting hundreds of billions of dollars from Medicaid, which could cause many poor residents of Wisconsin to lose BadgerCare Plus coverage. The bill focuses on structural changes to Medicaid, despite opposition from Democrats who warn it would throw millions off health coverage. Republicans emphasize reducing waste and fraud in the program as part of their rationale.

stories.headline: Van Orden calls to end spring elections
stories.summary: Wisconsin Republican U.S. Rep. Derrick Van Orden proposed eliminating spring elections, suggesting they be combined with partisan and nonpartisan races held in the fall. He argues spring elections are inefficient, expensive, and cause voter fatigue. The proposal would align the state's election schedule with others that hold major elections in the fall every two years. Republican leaders have not yet commented on the proposal.

stories.headline: On the rise: NFL, colleges, high schools push explosive popularity of flag football in Wisconsin
stories.summary: Flag football is rapidly gaining popularity among girls in Wisconsin, driven by efforts from the NFL and local schools. The sport's momentum is credited to the NFL's promotion and local advocates lobbying for programs to give girls competitive opportunities. Schools report an increase in teams and interest, making flag football one of the fastest-growing girls' sports in the state.

stories.headline: Trump administration bars Harvard from enrolling international students
stories.summary: The Trump administration revoked Harvard University's ability to enroll international students in an escalating battle with the Ivy League school, citing issues of a campus environment with anti-American and anti-Semitic activity. The Department of Homeland Security stated Harvard no longer enrolls foreign students and existing foreign students must transfer or lose their legal status, affecting about 6,800 foreign students at its Cambridge, Mass. campus.

stories.headline: Seattle's only homeless RV parking lot makes way for pickleball
stories.summary: Seattle's only parking lot for homeless people living in their RVs is closing to make room for a new three-story pickleball complex. The nonprofit operating the lot plans to reopen it at a new location soon. The Low Income Housing Institute had signed a lease to operate a designated space with services for people living in their vehicles but had to terminate the contract after progress was made on the development of the new facility.

stories.headline: State officials, hospitals blast Medicaid cuts in Republican budget bill as 'terrible,' 'cruel'
stories.summary: Several state elected officials and hospital leaders criticized a U.S. House vote approving billions of dollars in Medicaid cuts nationwide, which would impact around 200,000 Washingtonians and Apple Health coverage. The bill includes major tax break reductions while limiting funding to the Medicaid program, provoking opposition from leaders in Washington and Seattle.

stories.headline: At Space Needle, small rooms with a view
stories.summary: The Space Needle has introduced a new double-decker, all-glass outdoor elevator, which offers visitors a view as they ascend the 605-foot tower. The elevator is part of a $100 million renovation project, including 'Skyliner' elevator's gondolas, designed to give a new perspective of the landmark and is expected to be fully installed by 2028.

stories.headline: Washington school district defies state law, prohibits trans athletes
stories.summary: The Quilcene School Board voted to ban transgender athletes from competing in school sports, defying state law and the Washington Interscholastic Activities Association rules. The School Board passed the resolution with a 3-2 vote, with the Quilcene School District superintendent opposing the decision. The measure impacts about 73 total students in grades 9-12 in the district.
